instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: This Macbook came in with customer stating they had powering/charging issues with one of the ports, now it won't power from both USB-C. After replacing both <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips and still getting 5V 0.016A I checked the surrounding caps around them and found CF400/CF500 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> low at .560V. On further inspection I found a burnt coil L8300 which I replaced with a 30Ohm coil (all I had similar) to get 3.7V from <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> to <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> <SIGNAL>MPMU_BSTLQ_LX</SIGNAL>. Power was briefly at 5V 0.450A but has dropped to 5V 0.016A and I'm not sure where to look next.

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"L8300 which I replaced with a 30Ohm coil"
Did you read L8300 specs in schematic?

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes I did, I have no scrap boards available with a similar coil. I farmed L5001 from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> line

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
These are L8300 specs:
0.47UH  1.7A  0.175OHM

BTW, did you try DFU?

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Can I just run a wire for L8300 or could you suggest an alternative from any board <2017? Have I potentially damaged <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>?

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
L8300 is not just a simple series filter coil.
Is part of 5V boost-converter integrated into <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
There is a chance that master PMU can be damaged now.

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: It was pretty fried anyway so maybe the damage has already been done? I don't have a donor board for this model, I may have to write it off as a non fixable.

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Sorry, didn't read your previous message, the Macbook wouldn't enter DFU mode

threads.title: Macbook Air M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: If L8300 was already fried, very likely <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> was bad too.
